title: 104_hr125
content: The Act titled "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996" is also known as the "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996". The Congress finds that protecting citizens from armed violent criminals is crucial for public safety and prosperity. Banning specific firearms does not deter criminals, and the best way to safeguard the public is through arresting, convicting, and incarcerating violent offenders. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor for armed violent criminals and create a task force to develop strategies for removing them from the streets. The program considers the importance of severe punishment and the effectiveness of laws for apprehension and prosecution. The program considers the importance of severe punishment and the effectiveness of laws for apprehension and prosecution. The Attorney General shall require each United States attorney to report monthly on the number of defendants charged with violating specific sections of the United States Code in their district. The Attorney General appoints a prosecutor for armed violent criminals and establishes a task force to develop strategies for their removal. The Attorney General must report monthly on defendants charged with specific sections of the US Code. The Attorney General can waive requirements for US attorneys based on guidelines established. The Attorney General must submit information to Congress twice a year on waivers granted. The Attorney General appoints a prosecutor for armed violent criminals, defines the term "armed violent criminal," and sets a sunset provision for the section after a 5-year period. SEC. 4 repeals prohibitions on semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices by amending various sections of the United States Code. SEC. 5 mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm or destructive device during a federal crime that is a crime of violence or a drug trafficking crime. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include mandatory prison terms for possessing or brandishing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking crime. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, while brandishing leads to 10 years imprisonment. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, while discharging with intent to injure leads to 20 years imprisonment. Additional sentences apply for specific types of firearms, with penalties ranging from 10 to 30 years. Subsequent convictions result in increased penalties. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing leads to 25 years, and discharging with intent to injure results in additional penalties. Subsequent convictions result in increased penalties. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing leads to 25 years, and discharging with intent to injure results in additional penalties. Subsequent convictions result in increased penalties, including not less than 30 years imprisonment for certain firearms and life imprisonment for others. Probationary sentences are not allowed, and terms of imprisonment do not run concurrently with other offenses. No release is permitted during the term of imprisonment. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on March 22, 1996. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
